content.text: Use the set square provided to take readings from the metre rule to determine the unstretched length \(L\) of the coiled part of the spring. Record the value of \(L\)
Draw a diagram to show clearly how you used the set square to obtain an accurate reading from the metre rule
The metre rule is clamped in position near to the spring. Do **not** change the position of the metre rule
Suspend a load \(P = 0.20 \text{N}\) on the spring. Record in Table 1.1 the new length \(l\) of the spring
Repeat the procedure using loads \(P = 0.40 \text{N}\), \(0.60 \text{N}\), \(0.80 \text{N}\) and \(1.00 \text{N}\)
Plot a graph of \(l/\mathrm{mm}\) (y-axis) against \(P/\mathrm{N}\) (x-axis). Start both axes at the origin (0,0)

parts.label: (d)

content.text: The intercept on the \(y\)-axis of the graph is numerically equal to the length \(l_{0}\) of the spring when \(P = 0\). Determine the value of \(l_{0}\). Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information

issues: LaTeX subscript (_) found outside math mode

content.text: Calculate \(L - l_0\)
In this experiment, you will investigate the stretching of a spring
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1
Place the transparent block, largest face down, on the ray-trace sheet supplied. The block should be approximately in the middle of the paper
Draw and label the outline of the block ABCD
Remove the block and draw the normal NL at the centre of side AB. Continue the normal so that it passes through side CD of the block
Label the point \(\mathbf{F}\) where the normal NL crosses side AB
Label the point \(\mathbf{G}\) where the normal NL crosses side CD
• Draw the line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at an angle \(i = 30^{\circ}\) to the normal as shown in Fig. 2.1
• Place the paper on the pin board
• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) on line \(\mathbf{EF}\) at a suitable distance apart for this experiment

• Replace the block and look from the position of the eye shown in Fig. 2.1, to observe the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) through side \(\mathbf{CD}\) of the block. Adjust your line of sight until the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) appear one behind the other

• Place two pins \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\) between your eye and the block so that \(\mathsf{P}_3\), \(\mathsf{P}_4\), and the images of \(\mathsf{P}_1\) and \(\mathsf{P}_2\) seen through the block, appear one behind the other
• Label the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_1\), \(\mathsf{P}_2\), \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\)
• Remove the block and the pins

• Draw a line joining the positions of \(\mathsf{P}_3\) and \(\mathsf{P}_4\). Continue the line through the outline of the block until it extends to just outside the outline of the block. Label the end of the line \(\mathbf{K}\)
• Label the point \(\mathbf{H}\) where the line meets side \(\mathbf{CD}\)
• Label the point \(\mathbf{J}\) where the line meets the normal \(\mathbf{NL}\)
• Draw the line \(\mathbf{FH}\)
Measure and record the length \(a\) of the line \(\mathbf{GH}\)
Measure and record the length \(b\) of the line \(\mathbf{FH}\)
Measure and record the acute angle \(\theta\) between the line \(\mathbf{NL}\) and the line \(\mathbf{JK}\). An acute angle is less than \(90^{\circ}\)
State one precaution that you took in order to produce an accurate ray-trace

A student suggests that \(i\) should be equal to \(\theta\) within the limits of experimental accuracy. In this experiment, \(i = 30^{\circ}\). Suggest a range of values for \(\theta\) that match this suggestion for your experiment
A student plans to test the suggestion that, in this experiment, \(i = \theta\) for all possible values of \(i\)
Explain briefly how you would test the suggestion
Tie your ray-trace sheet into this Question Booklet between pages 6 and 7
In this experiment, you will investigate the refraction of light in a transparent block
Carry out the following instructions, using the separate ray-trace sheet provided. Refer to Fig. 2.1
• Switch on
• Measure the current \(I\) in the circuit

parts.label: (ii)

content.text: Connect the voltmeter across section BC of the resistance wire
Measure and record the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_{1}\) across section BC. Switch off

Measure and record the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_2\) across section CD. Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R_{2}\) of section CD using the equation \(R_{2} = \frac{V_{2}}{I}\) . Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment and include the unit

content.text: Disconnect the voltmeter and its leads from section CD. Connect the voltmeter across section DE. Switch on
Measure and record the potential difference (p.d.) \(V_3\) across section DE. Switch off
Calculate the resistance \(R_{3}\) of section DE using the equation \(R_{3} = \frac{V_{3}}{I}\) . Give your answer to a suitable number of significant figures for this experiment and include the unit
The sections BC, CD and DE are all the same length and made of the same metal
Tick the box to show your conclusion from the results
The resistance of a section increases as the number of wires increases
The resistance of a section decreases as the number of wires increases
The resistance of a section is independent of the number of wires
Justify your conclusion in (b)(i) by reference to your results
Explain how you would change this experiment to investigate the relationship between the length of a sample of wire and its resistance
In this experiment, you will investigate the resistance of samples of resistance wire
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1
The circuit shown in Fig. 3.1 has been provided for you
Table 3.1 shows how the samples of wire are connected into the circuit

table.html:
sectionresistance wire
BCone 30 cm piece
CDtwo 30 cm pieces
DEthree 30 cm pieces

content.text: A student investigates the length of time taken for ice cubes to melt when they are placed in water. She uses beakers of water at different temperatures to investigate how the initial temperature of the water affects the time taken for the ice cubes to melt
Plan an experiment to investigate how the initial temperature of the water affects the time taken for the ice cubes to melt. You are **not** required to carry out this experiment
The following apparatus is available:
thermometer
supply of ice cubes
250 cm³ beakers
supply of cold water
In your plan, you should:
• write a list of additional apparatus to use
• explain how to carry out the investigation
• state the key variables to keep constant
• draw a table, or tables, with column headings, to show how to display the readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table)
• explain how to use the readings to reach a conclusion
